item.title: Revisiting The Project Bootstrapping
item.description: Did you know that AVR is one microcontroller family that can be programmed by bit banging by hand? No computers or USB interfacing required, just plain physical, electrical on-and-offs. It’s true. The in-system programming (ISP) interface of AVR is concise enough that you can write to its flash memory an upwards of 10 to 20 instructions one bit at a time, with a reasonable amount of patience. In comparison, the JTAG type interface used by ARM and MIPS chips is too fiddly to program by hand, I discovered.
